xocs:funding-text.$: This work was supported by a Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Grant-in Aid for Young Scientists (B), grant number 16K18677 , and the Institute for Fermentation, Osaka . A part of this work was carried out through a collaboration established by the JSPS Core-to-Core Program “Establishment of an international research core for new bio-research fields with microbes from tropical areas (World-class research hub of tropical microbial resources and their utilization)” between Yamaguchi University, Chulalongkorn University, and Mahidol University. Appendix A

This work was supported by a Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Grant-in Aid for Young Scientists (B), grant number 16K18677, and the Institute for Fermentation, Osaka. A part of this work was carried out through a collaboration established by the JSPS Core-to-Core Program ?Establishment of an international research core for new bio-research fields with microbes from tropical areas (World-class research hub of tropical microbial resources and their utilization)? between Yamaguchi University, Chulalongkorn University, and Mahidol University.

organization.$: Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation
Research Center for Thermotolerant Microbial Resources
Biocatalyst and Environmental Biotechnology Research Unit
Center of Excellence in Hazardous Substance Management (HSM)

head.abstracts: © 2017 Elsevier LtdTo expand the diversity of chemical compounds produced through microbial conversion, a platform pathway for the production of widely used industrial chemicals, 1,3-diols, was engineered in Escherichia coli. The pathway was designed by modifying the previously reported (R)-1,3-butanediol synthetic pathway to consist of pct (propionate CoA-transferase) from Megasphaera elsdenii, bktB (thiolase), phaB (NADPH-dependent acetoacetyl-CoA reductase) from Ralstonia eutropha, bld (butyraldehyde dehydrogenase) from Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum, and the endogenous alcohol dehydrogenase(s) of E. coli. The recombinant E. coli strains produced 1,3-pentanediol, 4-methyl-1,3-pentanediol, and 1,2,4-butanetriol, together with 1,3-butanediol, from mixtures of glucose and propionate, isobutyrate, and glycolate, respectively, in shake flask cultures. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of microbial production of 1,3-pentanediol and 4-methyl-1,3-pentanediol.

organization.$: Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation

A part of this work was carried out through a collaboration established by the JSPS Core-to-Core Program “Establishment of an international research core for new bio-research fields with microbes from tropical areas (World-class research hub of tropical microbial resources and their utilization)” between Yamaguchi University, Chulalongkorn University, and Mahidol University.

coredata.dc:description: To expand the diversity of chemical compounds produced through microbial conversion, a platform pathway for the production of widely used industrial chemicals, 1,3-diols, was engineered in Escherichia coli. The pathway was designed by modifying the previously reported (R)-1,3-butanediol synthetic pathway to consist of pct (propionate CoA-transferase) from Megasphaera elsdenii, bktB (thiolase), phaB (NADPH-dependent acetoacetyl-CoA reductase) from Ralstonia eutropha, bld (butyraldehyde dehydrogenase) from Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum, and the endogenous alcohol dehydrogenase(s) of E. coli. The recombinant E. coli strains produced 1,3-pentanediol, 4-methyl-1,3-pentanediol, and 1,2,4-butanetriol, together with 1,3-butanediol, from mixtures of glucose and propionate, isobutyrate, and glycolate, respectively, in shake flask cultures. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of microbial production of 1,3-pentanediol and 4-methyl-1,3-pentanediol.
coredata.dc:title: Production of 1,3-diols in Escherichia coli
